standard_metadata.standard_description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{4}$ | $4, 8, 12, 16, \underline{\greenD{20}}$ $\maroonD{5}$ | $5, 10, 15, \underline{\greenD{20}}$ $\goldE{10}$| $10, \underline{\greenD{20}}, 30$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{20}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $20$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\dfrac{\blueD{1} \times 5}{\blueD{4} \times 5} = {\dfrac\blueD{5}\blueD{20}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{3} \times 4}{\maroonD{5} \times 4} = {\dfrac\maroonD{12}\maroonD{20}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{3}{10}}=\dfrac{\goldE{3} \times 2}{\goldE{10} \times 2} = {\dfrac\goldE{6}\goldE{20}} \end{align}$

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{5}$ | $5, \underline{\greenD{10}}, 15, 20$ $\maroonD{10}$ | $\underline{\greenD{10}}, 20, 30$ $\goldE{2}$| $2, 4, 6, 8, \underline{\greenD{10}}$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{10}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $10$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{5}}=\dfrac{\blueD{3} \times 2}{\blueD{5} \times 2} = {\dfrac\blueD{6}\blueD{10}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\goldE{1} \times 5}{\goldE{2} \times 5} = {\dfrac\goldE{5}\goldE{10}} \end{align}$

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{\greenD{12}}$ $\maroonD{6}$ | $6, \underline{\greenD{12}}, 18$ $\goldE{3}$| $3, 6, 9, \underline{\greenD{12}}$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\dfrac{\blueD{3} \times 3}{\blueD{4} \times 3} = {\dfrac\blueD{9}\blueD{12}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times 2}{\maroonD{6} \times2} = {\dfrac\maroonD{2}\maroonD{12}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\dfrac{\goldE{2} \times 4}{\goldE{3} \times4} = {\dfrac\goldE{8}\goldE{12}} \end{align}$

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{2}$ | $2, 4, \underline{\greenD{6}}$ $\maroonD{3}$ | $3, \underline{\greenD{6}}, 9$ $\goldE{6}$| $\underline{\greenD{6}}, 12, 18$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{6}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $6$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\blueD{1} \times 3}{\blueD{2} \times 3} = {\dfrac\blueD{3}\blueD{6}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times 2}{\maroonD{3} \times2} = {\dfrac\maroonD{2}\maroonD{6}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{5}{6}} \end{align}$
$\dfrac12 + \dfrac{1}{3} + \dfrac{5}{6} = \dfrac{10}{6}$  $\dfrac{10}6$ can also be written as $\dfrac53$ or $1\dfrac23$.

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{6}$ | $6, \underline{\greenD{12}}, 18$ $\maroonD{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{\greenD{12}}, 16$ $\goldE{3}$| $3, 6, 9, \underline{\greenD{12}}$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{6}}=\dfrac{\blueD{5} \times 2}{\blueD{6} \times2} = {\dfrac\blueD{10}\blueD{12}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{3} \times 3}{\maroonD{4} \times3} = {\dfrac\maroonD{9}\maroonD{12}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\dfrac{\goldE{2} \times 4}{\goldE{3} \times4} = {\dfrac\goldE{8}\goldE{12}} \end{align}$
${\dfrac{5}{6}} +{\dfrac{3}{4}} +{\dfrac{2}{3}} = \dfrac{27}{12}$  $\dfrac{27}{12}$ can also be written as $\dfrac{9}{4}$, or $2\dfrac14$.

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{2}$ | $2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, \underline{\greenD{18}}$ $\maroonD{6}$ | $6, 12, \underline{\greenD{18}}, 24$ $\goldE{9}$| $9, \underline{\greenD{18}}, 27$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{18}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $18$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{2}}=\dfrac{\blueD{3} \times 9}{\blueD{2} \times9} = {\dfrac\blueD{27}\blueD{18}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{5} \times 3}{\maroonD{6} \times3} = {\dfrac\maroonD{15}\maroonD{18}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{2}{9}}=\dfrac{\goldE{2} \times 2}{\goldE{9} \times2} = {\dfrac\goldE{4}\goldE{18}} \end{align}$

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{\greenD{12}}, 16$ $\maroonD{3}$ | $3, 6, 9, \underline{\greenD{12}}, 15$ $\goldE{2}$| $2, 4, 6, 8, 10, \underline{\greenD{12}}$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{4}}=\dfrac{\blueD{5} \times 3}{\blueD{4} \times3} = {\dfrac\blueD{15}\blueD{12}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times 4}{\maroonD{3} \times4} = {\dfrac\maroonD{4}\maroonD{12}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\goldE{1} \times 6}{\goldE{2} \times6} = {\dfrac\goldE{6}\goldE{12}} \end{align}$

Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueD{8}$ | $\underline{\greenD{8}}, 16, 24$ $\maroonD{4}$ | $4, \underline{\greenD{8}}, 12$ $\goldE{2}$| $2, 4, 6, \underline{\greenD{8}}$  The least common multiple is $\greenD{8}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $8$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{8}}\\\\ &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times 2}{\maroonD{4} \times2} = {\dfrac\maroonD{2}\maroonD{8}}\\\\ &\goldE{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\goldE{1} \times 4}{\goldE{2} \times4} = {\dfrac\goldE{4}\goldE{8}} \end{align}$

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\square + \dfrac{1}{16} = \dfrac{3}{2}$  **Which fraction makes the addition equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{2}$ | $2, 4,6,8, 10, 12, 14, \underline{\tealE{16}}$ $\maroonE{16}$ | $\underline{\tealE{16}}, 32$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{16}$.
Let's use multiplication to make $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}}$ have a denominator of $16$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{2}}=\dfrac{\blueE{3} \times 8}{\blueE{2} \times 8} = {\dfrac\blueE{24}\blueE{16}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 16 equal parts for a total of 32 equal parts. The first 23 parts are shaded brown. The next 1 part is shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 23 parts is labeled with an empty answer box. Across the next 1 part is a curved bracket labeled one sixteenth. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled twenty four-sixteenths.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 16 equal parts for a total of 32 equal parts. The first 23 parts are shaded brown. The next 1 part is shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 23 parts is labeled twenty three sixteenths. Across the next 1 part is a curved bracket labeled one sixteenth. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled twenty four-sixteenths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\dfrac{2}{5} + \square = \dfrac{7}{10}$  **Which fraction makes the addition equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{5}$ | $5, \underline{\tealE{10}}, 15$ $\maroonE{10}$ | $\underline{\tealE{10}}, 20, 30$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{10}$.
Let's use multiplication to make $\blueE{\dfrac{2}{5}}$ have a denominator of $10$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{2}{5}}=\dfrac{\blueE{2} \times 2}{\blueE{5} \times 2} = {\dfrac\blueE{4}\blueE{10}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into ten equal parts. The first four parts are shaded in blue. The next three parts are shaded in brown. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first four parts is labeled four-tenths. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled with an empty box. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seven-tenths.

A tape diagram divided into ten equal parts. The first four parts are shaded in blue. The next three parts are shaded in brown. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first four parts is labeled four-tenths. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled three-tenths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seven-tenths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\dfrac{1}{2} + \square = \dfrac{7}{8}$  **Which fraction makes the addition equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{2}$ | $2, 4, 6, \underline{\tealE{8}}, 10$ $\maroonE{8}$ | $\underline{\tealE{8}}, 16, 24$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{8}$.
Let's use multiplication to make $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ have a denominator of $8$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\blueE{1} \times 4}{\blueE{2} \times 4} = {\dfrac\blueE{4}\blueE{8}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into eight equal parts. The first four parts are shaded in blue. The next three parts are shaded in brown. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first four parts is labeled four-eighths. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled with an empty box. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seven-eighths.

A tape diagram divided into eight equal parts. The first four parts are shaded in blue. The next three parts are shaded in brown. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first four parts is labeled four-eighths. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled three-eighths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seven-eighths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\square + \dfrac{1}{3} = \dfrac{3}{4}$  **Which fraction makes the addition equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{3}$ | $3,6, 9, \underline{\tealE{12}}, 15$ $\maroonE{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{\tealE{12}}, 16$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\dfrac{\blueE{1} \times 4}{\blueE{3} \times 4} = {\dfrac\blueE{4}\blueE{12}}$  $\maroonE{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\dfrac{\maroonE{3} \times 3}{\maroonE{4} \times 3} = {\dfrac\maroonE{9}\maroonE{12}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into twelve equal parts. The first five parts are shaded in brown. The next four parts are shaded in blue. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first five parts is labeled with an empty answer box. Across the next four parts is a curved bracket labeled four-twelfths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled nine-twelfths.

A tape diagram divided into twelve equal parts. The first five parts are shaded in brown. The next four parts are shaded in blue. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first five parts is labeled five-twelfths. Across the next four parts is a curved bracket labeled four-twelfths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled nine-twelfths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\square - \dfrac{3}{4} = \dfrac{2}{3}$  **Which fraction makes the subtraction equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{\tealE{12}}, 16$ $\maroonE{3}$ | $3, 6, 9, \underline{\tealE{12}}, 15$  The least common multiple is $\tealE{12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\dfrac{\blueE{3} \times 3}{\blueE{4} \times 3} = {\dfrac\blueE{9}\blueE{12}}$  $\maroonE{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\dfrac{\maroonE{2} \times 4}{\maroonE{3} \times 4} = {\dfrac\maroonE{8}\maroonE{12}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 12 equal parts for a total of 24 equal parts. The first 9 parts are shaded blue. The next eight parts are shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 9 parts is labeled nine-twelfths. Across the next 8 parts is a curved bracket labeled eight-twelfths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled with an empty box.

A tape diagram with two tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 12 equal parts for a total of 24 equal parts. The first 9 parts are shaded blue. The next eight parts are shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 9 parts is labeled nine-twelfths. Across the next 8 parts is a curved bracket labeled eight-twelfths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seventeen-twelfths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\square - \dfrac{3}{10} = \dfrac{1}{5}$  **Which fraction makes the subtraction equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{10}$ | $\underline{\tealE{10}}, 20, 30$ $\maroonE{5}$ | $5, \underline{\tealE{10}}, 15$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{10}$.
Let's use multiplication to make $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ have a denominator of $10$.  $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{5}}=\dfrac{\maroonE{1} \times 2}{\maroonE{5} \times 2} = {\dfrac\maroonE{2}\maroonE{10}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into ten equal parts. The first three parts are shaded in blue. The next two parts are shaded in pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first three parts is labeled three-tenths. Across the next two parts is a curved bracket labeled two-tenths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled with an empty box.

A tape diagram divided into ten equal parts. The first three parts are shaded in blue. The next two parts are shaded in pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first three parts is labeled three-tenths. Across the next two parts is a curved bracket labeled two-tenths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled five-tenths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\dfrac{5}{6} - \square = \dfrac{1}{2}$  **Which fraction makes the subtraction equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{6}$ | $\underline{\tealE{6}}, 12, 18$ $\maroonE{2}$ | $2, 4, \underline{\tealE{6}}, 8, 10$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{6}$.
Let's use multiplication to make $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ have a denominator of $6$.  $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{\maroonE{1} \times 3}{\maroonE{2} \times 3} = {\dfrac\maroonE{3}\maroonE{6}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram divided into six equal parts. The first two parts are shaded in orange. The next three parts are shaded in pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first two parts is labeled with an empty answer box. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled three-sixths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled five-sixths.

A tape diagram divided into six equal parts. The first two parts are shaded in orange. The next three parts are shaded in pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first two parts is labeled two-sixths. Across the next three parts is a curved bracket labeled three-sixths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled five-sixths.

question.content: Look at the equation below.   $\dfrac{5}{2} - \square = \dfrac{1}{3}$  **Which fraction makes the subtraction equation true?**

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\blueE{2}$ | $2, 4, \underline{\tealE{6}}$ $\maroonE{3}$ | $3, \underline{\tealE{6}}, 9$   The least common multiple is $\tealE{6}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $6$.  $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{2}}=\dfrac{\blueE{5} \times 3}{\blueE{2} \times 3} = {\dfrac\blueE{15}\blueE{6}}$  $\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\dfrac{\maroonE{1} \times 2}{\maroonE{3} \times 2} = {\dfrac\maroonE{2}\maroonE{6}}$

images.alt: A tape diagram with three tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 6 equal parts for a total of 18 equal parts. The first 13 parts are shaded brown. The next 2 parts are shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 13 parts is labeled with an empty answer box. Across the next 2 parts is a curved bracket labeled two-sixths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled fifteen-sixths.

A tape diagram with three tapes of equal length side by side. Each tape is divided into 6 equal parts for a total of 18 equal parts. The first 13 parts are shaded brown. The next 2 parts are shaded pink. Above the tape, a curved bracket across the first 13 parts is labeled thirteen-sixths. Across the next 2 parts is a curved bracket labeled two-sixths. Below the tape, a curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled fifteen-sixths.
